title: Robust sensitivity control in digital pathology via tile score distribution matching
author: Arthur Pignet (Owkin, Inc), John Klein (Owkin, Inc), Geneviève Robin (Owkin, Inc), Antoine Olivier (Owkin, Inc), ...
background: Controlling sensitivity in classification tasks while using deep learning models on whole slide images in digital pathology.
contribution: This paper introduces Tile-Score Matching (TSM) to solve the sensitivity transferability issue in WSI classification, achieving robust sensitivity control with minimal calibration samples.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous methods, such as Unsupervised Prediction Alignment, require numerous whole slide images for calibration, complicating deployment.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work improves by enabling calibration at the tile level rather than at the WSI level, requiring fewer calibration samples (less than 30) for effective sensitivity control.

key_innovation: TSM leverages optimal transport methods to match the tile-level score distributions between training and validation cohorts, enhancing sensitivity consistency.
real_world_impact: The proposed method allows for more reliable deployment of digital pathology systems across various medical centers, potentially improving diagnostic outcomes.
limitations: The method is specifically tailored for the Chowder architecture, which may limit applicability to other Multiple Instance Learning models.

new_terms.Tile-Score Matching: **Tile-Score Matching (TSM)** is a novel calibration technique that aligns distribution of scores for individual tiles from whole slide images to control sensitivity in classification tasks.
new_terms.Optimal Transport: **Optimal Transport** is a mathematical theory that deals with the movement of distributions, allowing for the efficient matching of different probability measures.

open_sourcing: Code, model, and features are available at https://anonymous.4open.science/r/tsm
